Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer's selective use of country reports and omission of contrary evidence constitutes an error of law
Application_Facts: Applicant claims the PRRA officer ignored relevant evidence about Sri Lanka's conditions
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no error of law found in the PRRA decision
Court_Ruling: The officer's decision was not patently unreasonable
Defendant_Behavior: PRRA Officer selectively used country reports and omitted contrary evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged failure to consider all relevant evidence regarding risk upon return to Sri Lanka
Assessment_Factor: General improvements in Sri Lanka’s human rights and security conditions
Procedural_Issue: Standard of review for PRRA decisions
Evidence_Used: Country reports on Sri Lanka's conditions
Application_Basis: Risk upon return to Sri Lanka
Relief_Sought: Overturn of PRRA denial and reassessment
Governing_Rule: Standard of review is patent unreasonableness; court does not re-weigh evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged omission of evidence contrary to the officer’s conclusion
Harm_Assessment: Potential risk upon removal to Sri Lanka
Cause_Description: Applicant's PRRA application was denied, prompting a judicial review alleging selective evidence use
Evidence_Handling: Officer relied on general country reports while applicant alleged omission of adverse evidence
Evidence_Issues: Selective use of evidence, omission of potentially contrary reports
Evidence_Assessment: Court found that omitted evidence did not significantly alter the core claim
Decision_Rationale: The decision was not patently unreasonable as the core risk assessment remained supported by evidence
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to include all relevant country condition evidence
